SENT.plain: The microchemical study of growth cartilage biopsies may improve the classification and the genetic advice of some types of growth disturbances and contribute to the understanding of biochemical defects

Small tibial growth cartilage biopsies were performed during orthopedic surgery in cases with achondroplasia, pseudoachondroplasis (three cases), Kniest's disease (two cases), diastrophic dwarfism (two cases), parastrematic dwarfism, pycnodysos tosis, mucolipidosis type III, Blount's disease, and in three normal growing children
Five human fetal cartilages were also studied
The proteoglycans were extracted with 4 M guanidinium chloride
After dialysis against 8 M urea at pH 7, the proteoglycans were obtained by ion chromatography in urea on DEAE-cellulose and submitted to gel electrophoresis on polyacrylamide-agarose gels
The gel electrophoresis of the proteoglycans of growth cartilage of normal growing children gave two metachromatic bands situated close one to another
The proteoglycans extracted from fetal growth cartilage gave a single band with a slightly slower migration
An abnormal gel electrophoretic pattern was found in pseudoachondroplasia and in Kniest's disease
In pseudoachondroplasia a single wide band was found; in overcharged tubes several thin, more rapid bands appeared in addition to the main band
In Kniest's disease three bands were found
In all of the other syndromes studied two normally or almost normally situated bands were present
Small differences in the width and intensity of the bands observed in several cases were difficult to assess

In all cases except mucolipidosis III and Kniest's disease the collagen was extracted by using limited cleavage and solubilization with pepsin, purified and analyzed by polyacrylamide gel electrophoresis
A type of collagen with a single alpha band was found
